subject: Aerospace Engineering
question_text: If f(θ) = [[cos θ, sin θ], [-sin θ, cos θ]], then f(α)f(β) =

tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This question requires understanding matrix multiplication and trigonometric identities to determine the resulting matrix. It's an application of matrix properties rather than a direct calculation or derivation.

answer_validation.reasoning:
The given matrix $f(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \theta & \sin \theta \\ -\sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{bmatrix}$ represents a 2D rotation. When two rotation matrices are multiplied, their angles add up. Therefore, the product of $f(\alpha)$ and $f(\beta)$ will correspond to a rotation by the sum of their effective angles.

Let's perform the matrix multiplication:
$f(\alpha) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \alpha & \sin \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha \end{bmatrix}$
$f(\beta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \beta & \sin \beta \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta \end{bmatrix}$

$f(\alpha)f(\beta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \alpha & \sin \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & \cos \alpha \end{bmatrix} \times \begin{bmatrix} \cos \beta & \sin \beta \\ -\sin \beta & \cos \beta \end{bmatrix}$

Performing the matrix multiplication element by element:

$(1,1)$ element: $(\cos \alpha)(\cos \beta) + (\sin \alpha)(-\sin \beta) = \cos \alpha \cos \beta - \sin \alpha \sin \beta$
Using the trigonometric identity $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$, this simplifies to $\cos(\alpha + \beta)$.

$(1,2)$ element: $(\cos \alpha)(\sin \beta) + (\sin \alpha)(\cos \beta) = \cos \alpha \sin \beta + \sin \alpha \cos \beta$
Using the trigonometric identity $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$, this simplifies to $\sin(\alpha + \beta)$.

$(2,1)$ element: $(-\sin \alpha)(\cos \beta) + (\cos \alpha)(-\sin \beta) = -\sin \alpha \cos \beta - \cos \alpha \sin \beta = -(\sin \alpha \cos \beta + \cos \alpha \sin \beta)$
Using the trigonometric identity $\sin(A+B) = \sin A \cos B + \cos A \sin B$, this simplifies to $-\sin(\alpha + \beta)$.

$(2,2)$ element: $(-\sin \alpha)(\sin \beta) + (\cos \alpha)(\cos \beta) = -\sin \alpha \sin \beta + \cos \alpha \cos \beta = \cos \alpha \cos \beta - \sin \alpha \sin \beta$
Using the trigonometric identity $\cos(A+B) = \cos A \cos B - \sin A \sin B$, this simplifies to $\cos(\alpha + \beta)$.

Combining these elements, the resulting matrix is:
$f(\alpha)f(\beta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(\alpha + \beta) & \sin(\alpha + \beta) \\ -\sin(\alpha + \beta) & \cos(\alpha + \beta) \end{bmatrix}$

This resulting matrix is precisely in the form of $f(\theta)$ with $\theta = (\alpha + \beta)$. Therefore, $f(\alpha)f(\beta) = f(\alpha + \beta)$. The correct option is B.

step_by_step: Identify the given matrix function $f(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos \theta & \sin \theta \ -\sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{bmatrix}$. Recognize that this matrix represents a 2D rotation.
Write down the matrices $f(\alpha)$ and $f(\beta)$ by substituting $\theta$ with $\alpha$ and $\beta$ respectively.
Compute the (1,1) element: $(\cos \alpha)(\cos \beta) + (\sin \alpha)(-\sin \beta) = \cos \alpha \cos \beta - \sin \alpha \sin \beta = \cos(\alpha+\beta)$ using the cosine addition formula.
Compute the (1,2) element: $(\cos \alpha)(\sin \beta) + (\sin \alpha)(\cos \beta) = \cos \alpha \sin \beta + \sin \alpha \cos \beta = \sin(\alpha+\beta)$ using the sine addition formula.
Assemble the result: $f(\alpha)f(\beta) = \begin{bmatrix} \cos(\alpha+\beta) & \sin(\alpha+\beta) \ -\sin(\alpha+\beta) & \cos(\alpha+\beta) \end{bmatrix} = f(\alpha+\beta)$. This matches option B.
formulas_used: [[a, b], [c, d]] \times [[e, f], [g, h]] = [[ae+bg, af+bh], [ce+dg, cf+dh]]

topic.name: Linear Algebra
topic.syllabus_ref: GATE AE Syllabus -> Engineering Mathematics -> Linear Algebra -> Matrices

helpful: Knowledge of rotation matrices and their properties

Rotation Matrix Multiplication: enables: Group theory applications in linear transformations

difficulty_factors: Requires recall and correct application of trigonometric sum identities.

textbook_references.author: B.S. Grewal
textbook_references.section: Matrix Multiplication, Orthogonal Matrices, Linear Transformations
textbook_references.text_snippet: The product of two rotation matrices is also a rotation matrix. If `A_θ` and `A_ϕ` are rotation matrices, then `A_θ A_ϕ = A_θ+ϕ`.

textbook_references.author: Erwin Kreyszig
textbook_references.text_snippet: Rotation transformation: $A_\theta = [[cos(θ), -sin(θ)], [sin(θ), cos(θ)]]$. Rotation matrices are orthogonal.

video_references.topic_covered: Rotation Transformation and derivation of rotation matrix

step_by_step_solution.approach_type: Direct Matrix Multiplication and Trigonometric Simplification
step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify Rotation Matrix Properties → Perform Matrix Multiplication → Apply Trigonometric Simplification → Compare Result with Options
key_insights: The product of two rotation matrices is another rotation matrix whose angle is the sum of the individual angles, i.e., f(α)f(β) = f(α + β).
The trigonometric addition formulas are essential for simplifying the product of rotation matrices.

formulas_principles.name: Clockwise Rotation Matrix
formulas_principles.conditions: Represents a 2D clockwise rotation by angle $\theta$ about the origin.
formulas_principles.relevance: The core matrix definition given in the problem.

formulas_principles.name: Rotation Matrix Group Property
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to 2D rotation matrices of the same form (same orientation).
formulas_principles.relevance: Key property used to simplify the matrix multiplication and solve the question.

formulas_principles.name: Cosine Sum Identity
formulas_principles.relevance: Essential for simplifying the (1,1) and (2,2) elements of the product matrix.

formulas_principles.name: Sine Sum Identity
formulas_principles.relevance: Essential for simplifying the (1,2) and (2,1) elements of the product matrix.

industry_examples: Computer Graphics and Animation: Used for rotating objects, cameras, and coordinate systems in 2D and 3D space.
Robotics: Used to describe the orientation and movement of robotic arms and end-effectors.
Aerospace Engineering: Used in flight dynamics for transforming between different coordinate systems (e.g., body axes to earth axes), attitude control, and navigation.
specific_systems: Attitude control systems in spacecraft and aircraft rely on rotation matrices to maintain proper orientation
Flight simulators use rotation matrices to update aircraft orientation.
CAD/CAM software for design and manufacturing
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding rotation matrices is fundamental for describing and controlling the orientation and motion of objects in space, which is critical in many engineering disciplines, including robotics, aerospace, and computer vision.

common_mistakes.mistake: Mistaking the given rotation matrix for the standard counter-clockwise rotation matrix, leading to sign errors, or general incorrect matrix multiplication.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: The standard rotation matrix is more common, leading students to recall it automatically without checking the given matrix. Also, carelessness in multiplying rows by columns, especially with negative signs.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always write down the given matrices explicitly and carefully before multiplying. Note the signs of the sine terms. Practice matrix multiplication diligently and double-check each element calculation.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an entirely wrong matrix, incorrect product, and an incorrect option selection.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrect application or forgetting of trigonometric sum/difference identities for simplification.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Forgetting the exact form of sum/difference identities (e.g., confusing $\cos(A+B)$ with $\cos(A-B)$) or making sign errors. Lack of practice in simplifying trigonometric expressions.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Memorize trigonometric identities or quickly derive them if unsure. Pay close attention to signs during substitution. Practice combining trigonometric expressions.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a matrix that might resemble one of the options but with incorrect signs or angles, resulting in a wrong answer, or being stuck with an unsimplified expression.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not recognizing $f(\theta)$ as a rotation matrix (or its transpose) and its compositional properties.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Lack of familiarity with standard transformation matrices or their properties.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Thoroughly study the properties and characteristics of different types of matrices, including rotation matrices. Understand that sequential rotations compose by adding angles.
common_mistakes.consequence: Might make the problem seem more complex than it is, leading to a longer solution path, or missing simplification opportunities, and potentially incorrect answers if properties are misapplied.
Might select option A or C incorrectly.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that rotation matrices commute, but the functional form is still f(α+β), not f(αβ) or f(α/β).
common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming the product is commutative and equals f(αβ) or f(α/β).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Misunderstanding of matrix multiplication (non-commutative in general, but rotation matrices do commute).

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: ROT-ADD: ROTation matrices ADD angles when multiplied.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: The product of two rotation matrices $R(\alpha)R(\beta)$ results in a rotation matrix $R(\alpha+\beta)$, meaning multiplication of rotation matrices corresponds to addition of angles.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When dealing with sequential rotations or composition of rotational transformations, especially when multiplying rotation matrices of the same type (same axis). For the given matrix $f(\theta) = R(-\theta)$, the property still holds: $f(\alpha)f(\beta) = R(-\alpha)R(-\beta) = R(-(\alpha+\beta)) = f(\alpha+\beta)$.
To recall the form of the rotation matrix.
mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: COS-SIN Sign Check: For clockwise rotation, sine in first row is positive? Actually, the given matrix is clockwise. Remember: 'Clockwise Sine Swap'? Better to derive or remember the standard and then adjust.

flashcards.front: What is the 2D counter-clockwise rotation matrix for angle \theta?
Given two rotation matrices `f(α)` and `f(β)`, find the resulting rotation matrix.
flashcards.back: The resulting rotation matrix is `f(α + β)`.

flashcards.front: What is a common mistake students make when dealing with rotation matrices?
flashcards.back: Confusing the product of rotation matrices with the sum of the rotation angles. The correct relationship is `f(α)f(β) = f(α + β)`.

flashcards.front: How to avoid matrix multiplication errors?
flashcards.back: Double-check each element calculation by explicitly writing out (row i) · (column j). Pay careful attention to signs, especially with trigonometric functions.
An orthogonal matrix A satisfies $A^T = A^{-1}$. Rotation matrices are orthogonal matrices with determinant +1.
flashcards.front: What is an orthogonal matrix? How is a rotation matrix related?

real_world_context.application: Aircraft attitude control and navigation in aerospace vehicles
real_world_context.industry_example: In an aircraft's Inertial Navigation System (INS), rotation matrices are continuously used to transform acceleration and angular rate measurements from the aircraft's body frame to an Earth-fixed navigation frame. This allows the system to track the aircraft's position, velocity, and attitude relative to the ground. Similarly, satellite attitude control systems use rotation matrices to maintain correct orientation.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Accurate and efficient computation of these transformations is critical for stable flight, precise navigation, and the overall safety and performance of aerospace vehicles. Errors in rotation matrix calculations can lead to significant navigation drift, control instabilities, or deviation from mission objectives.

real_world_context.industry_example: A robotic arm's end-effector orientation is determined by multiplying rotation matrices for each joint. The overall rotation is the product of individual rotations.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Accurate computation is essential for the robot to reach the desired position and orientation.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Quickly recognize the matrix form as a rotation matrix. The key property is that the product is another rotation matrix by the sum of the angles, which allows for quick elimination of options without full calculation.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: Remember that the product of rotation matrices is another rotation matrix, and the angles add. Therefore, options involving angle addition/subtraction are plausible. The zero matrix is highly unlikely as rotation matrices are invertible.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate 1-3 minutes. If the properties of rotation matrices are not immediately recalled, consider flagging it for later. A quick check of one element (e.g., (1,1)) can sometimes reveal the pattern.

alternative_methods.name: Complex Number Representation
alternative_methods.description: A 2D vector $(x, y)$ can be represented as a complex number $z = x + iy$. A counter-clockwise rotation by $\theta$ is equivalent to multiplying $z$ by $e^{i\theta} = \cos \theta + i \sin \theta$. The given matrix $f(\theta)$ corresponds to a clockwise rotation by $\theta$, which is equivalent to multiplication by $e^{-i\theta} = \cos \theta - i \sin \theta$. Thus, $f(\alpha)$ corresponds to $e^{-i\alpha}$ and $f(\beta)$ corresponds to $e^{-i\beta}$. Their product would be $e^{-i\alpha} \times e^{-i\beta} = e^{-i(\alpha+\beta)} = \cos(\alpha+\beta) - i \sin(\alpha+\beta)$. This complex number corresponds to the matrix $f(\alpha+\beta)$.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Elegant and often quicker for composing multiple 2D rotations. Provides a deeper mathematical insight into rotations. Simpler multiplication. Cons: Requires familiarity with complex numbers and their geometric interpretation, which might not be intuitive for all students. Only works for 2D rotations.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When dealing with multiple 2D rotations, or when complex numbers are already part of the problem context. It's a good method for verification, especially if you are comfortable with complex numbers.

alternative_methods.description: A rotation by α followed by a rotation by β is equivalent to a single rotation by α+β. Since f(θ) represents a rotation, the product must be f(α+β).
alternative_methods.name: Geometric Intuition
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: No calculation needed, quick. Cons: Requires strong conceptual understanding; may not be convincing without proof.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: For multiple-choice questions where you can eliminate other options.

connections_to_other_subjects.Physics: Rotational motion, rigid body dynamics, coordinate transformations in classical mechanics.
connections_to_other_subjects.Computer Graphics: Fundamental for 2D and 3D transformations, object manipulation, and camera control in graphics engines and animation software.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Used in state-space representations for systems involving rotational dynamics and in designing attitude control systems for aircraft and spacecraft.
connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Essential for understanding aircraft attitude, transforming forces and moments between different reference frames, and analyzing stability derivatives.
connections_to_other_subjects.Engineering Mechanics: Used in rigid body dynamics for coordinate transformations.
connections_to_other_subjects.Linear Algebra: Rotation matrices are a specific type of orthogonal matrices, which have many important properties in linear algebra.
connections_to_other_subjects.Robotics: Rotation matrices are extensively used in the kinematics and control of robotic manipulators to represent and transform spatial orientations.
